@graph.title: The evolution of host plant use and adaptation to Brassicaceae in the leaf beetle genus Psylliodes
@graph.abstract: The leaf beetle genus Psylliodes comprises about 200 species that are associated with host plants in at least 24 different families. Diet breadth varies among Psylliodes species but the majority uses host plants belonging to a single plant family, predominantly within the Brassicaceae, Solanaceae, or Fagaceae. These plant families produce diverse defense metabolites including glucosinolates, alkaloids, and tannins, raising questions about how this pattern of host use evolved and how Psylliodes species have adapted to such different hosts. Here, I inferred the diversification patterns of 60 Psylliodes species and found that most Brassicaceae, Solanaceae, and Fagaceae-associated species formed separate clades with polyphagous species being nested within and between groups of specialized species. An ancestral host reconstruction suggests that Psylliodes species specialized on distinct plant families from polyphagous ancestors, whereas direct host switches from one plant family to another have been rare. Host specialization followed by species diversification can be facilitated by a novel counteradaptation to a host-specific chemical defence. I thus analysed the evolution of a detoxification mechanism that deactivates glucosinolates, the characteristic defense metabolites in Brassicaceae, by enzymatic desulfation. I demonstrate that a conserved arylsulfatase gene had duplicated in the genome of Psylliodes prior to specialization on Brassicaceae, which enabled the evolution of a novel detoxifying function in the context of adaptation to a specific host. Together, the results suggest that changes in diet breadth and the evolution of specialized detoxification strategies played a role in the diversification of Psylliodes flea beetles.
